description: From Latin perforō (“I bore or pierce through; I perforate”), from per- (“through, thorough”) + forō (“I bore, I pierce”).

examples: A species of remarkable appearance with mature leaf laminae often so profoundly perforate as to resemble a fragile net of tissue.

verbs.description: perforate (third-person singular simple present perforates, present participle perforating, simple past and past participle perforated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make a line of holes in (a thin material) to allow separation at the line.
examples: to perforate a sheet of postage stamps
